Award.AwardTitle: Complex role of solvation in protein structure and dynamics in micelles and membranes
Award.AbstractNarration:
One of the great challenges in biological chemistry is to develop a fundamental understanding of how protein structure informs function. By encapsulating proteins in surfactant micelles (nanoscale molecular aggregates, such as a droplet in a colloidal system), experimental studies have shown that critical insights can be gained into protein structure, dynamics, and function. Currently, however, no one knows how the micelle environment influences the structure and dynamics of the encapsulated proteins. In this project, funded by the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor John Straub of Boston University leads a computational study to develop a fundamental understanding of the nature and potential applications of protein encapsulation in micelles.

The project involves a systematic computational study of the effect of varying surfactant properties on the structure and dynamics of micelle encapsulated proteins. Through a novel multiscale computational approach, the influence of surfactant (anionic, cationic, and mixtures) and relative impact of generic (confinement geometry, spatially-dependent pressure profile) and surfactant specific contributions, on properties such as association equilibria, hydration dynamics, and channel function, will be explored. Novel and traditional approaches will be employed to analyze structure, dynamics, and function for comparison with observables from NMR and vibrational spectroscopy. The broader impact of the study is the promotion of graduate education in computational biophysics through the development of a summer school for graduate training in state-of-the-art computational and experimental methods in the field of biomolecular structure and dynamics. Participating students will be selected to provide a balance of experimentalists and theorists, women and men, with a strong involvement of underrepresented minorities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Surfactants are special molecules that posses a "head" that likes water and a "tail" that does not.  When surfactants are mixed with water and oil, they assemble to form remarkable structures.  Micelles are surfactant droplets, with heads pointing outward toward water and tails pointing inward.  Molecules of grease dissolve inside micelles making surfactants important in cleaning technology.  More modern uses of micelles include the encapsulation of protein, facilitating the resolution of protein structure using magnetic resonance experiments (see Figure 1). 

When there is more oil than water in solution, the surfactant molecules can assemble to form ``reverse micelles'' in which the tails face outward and heads face inward toward ``nanopools'' of water.  Reverse micelles can also be used to encapsulate protein facilitating the resolution of protein structure (see Figure 1). 

The driving force for the formation of these remarkable structures is simple.  The surfactant molecules want to keep their heads in water and their tails out of water.  However, despite many years of study key questions regarding the nature of surfactant micelles and reverse micelles remain unanswered.  The research supported by this award facilitated the development of new computational models and methods for the detailed study of micelle solutions using large-scale computer simulation. 

Lipid membranes share many of the properties of surfactant micelles.  They are formed of lipid (fat) molecules that have ``heads'' that love water and tails that do not.  The lipids assemble into two opposing sheets forming a "bi-layer" with heads facing outward toward water and tails facing inward toward one another (see Figure 2).  The lipid bilayer structure forms the basis for cellular membranes in biology.  The computational methods developed to explore questions related to micelle and reverse micelle structure were additionally applied to address questions related to lipid bilayer structure and function, including studies of the structure of proteins ``dissolved'' and assembled in lipid bilayers (see Figure 3).

Key outcomes of our research include (1) addressing a 40 year-old question regarding the structure and stability of cholesterol dimer formation in membrane, (2) unique thermodynamic insight into water ordering near hydrophilic, polar, and charged interfaces in micelles and reverse micelles essential to their ability to encapsulate protein, (3) the development of a first-principles approach to the determination of micelle size distributions, and (4) insight into the structure and stability of lipid "raft" microdomains in complex lipid bilayers. 

The products of our research include peer-reviewed publications describing the development of new computational and theoretical "tools" for the study of complex surfactant mixtures and membrane, and insight into the fundamental nature of solvation in surfactant micelle and complex lipid bilayers.  The broader impacts of our research include the training of graduate students and postdoctoral fellows, in our research group, and the organization of a summer school that provided training for 24 graduate students in state-of-the-art methods in the theoretical and experimental study of protein structure and dynamics.

Our long-term goals are the development of methods for the design of new surfactant mixtures with special properties and the identification of principles governing membrane protein structure and function.  In pursing these goals, we are committed to making a special effort to enhance the training of the next generation of research leaders in the field of computational molecular science.
